Every day, headlines regarding the college price issue arise. But what exactly is the crisis that we are attempting to resolve? Is it the excessive amount of student debt? Higher education’s skyrocketing costs? What about the interest on student loans? Why is there such a high default rate on student loans? Or perhaps all of the above?

For many, the main issue is the amount of student loan debt they have accrued. Student loan debt, at roughly $1.6 trillion, outnumbers car loans and even credit card debt. This is a problem by nearly any definition: It is unquestionably a problem for people who have student loan loans with repayment plans that extend decades and need substantial monthly payments.

Below is a look at some of the most common methods of supporting a college education, as well as some suggested strategies for maximizing those resources. We’ve also included a few unusual funding options to assist students get the money they need without accumulating a mountain of debt.

Loans

Loans are accessible through federal and state government programs, as well as banks and other private financial institutions. Federal student loans are by far the most popular, owing to lower interest rates and a variety of payment alternatives.
Here are a few pointers to help students avoid the dangers of loan debt and the implications of loan default.

Strategies:

Borrow only what is necessary to pay for education. Students are not compelled to accept the whole amount of the loan provided to them. The rule should be: if you don’t need everything, don’t take everything.

  • Working while attending college. A part-time or temporary work will reduce the loan amount and/or assist with loan repayment.
  • Making student debt installments before to graduation. Although it is not always       practicable, beginning to repay a loan while still in school implies having less to pay later.
  • Make a larger monthly payment than the minimum. This will result in significant long-term savings in total interest paid during the loan term.

Scholarships

Everyone is aware of scholarship opportunities. Or, at least, they believe they do. The most well-known attribute of scholarships is that they do not have to be paid back. Scholarships are also available everywhere. Professional associations, nonprofit organizations and philanthropic groups, private enterprises and firms, government agencies, and even individuals offer thousands of them. Colleges and universities are also a significant source of scholarship monies.
The key to obtaining a scholarship – or more – is for students to seek out and apply for those for which they are plainly eligible. That will take some serious time and effort. Each scholarship has its own set of eligibility criteria.

Strategies:

  • Begin Early: As previously said, locating the appropriate scholarships to apply for takes time and effort. The earlier students and parents begin their search, the better. And it may be as early as freshman year of high school, but no later than the start of junior year.
  • High School Resources: Guidance counselors are the primary resource for college planning and funding on a high school campus. When looking for scholarship options, students and parents should make full use of guidance counseling services.
  • Extracurricular and Community Activities: Many scholarships consider factors other than an applicant’s academic performance. Many people think about the personal aspects that make a student unique, and this typically involves looking at their extracurricular activities.
  • Don’t Put Your Scholarship Search on Hold Once You’re in College: Many scholarships are available – sometimes solely – to students who have completed their first year of college.

Fellowships and Assistantships.

Fellowships are typically given to students in order for them to conduct in-depth research on a certain issue related to their primary field of study. Assistantships entail collaborating closely with teachers and staff in teaching, research, and administrative roles. Fellowships and assistantships are normally solely accessible to graduate students, but jobs are occasionally made available to undergraduates. Fellowships are typically compensated in the form of a living allowance or stipend. Assistants are often compensated with a salary, tuition reimbursement, and other fringe benefits.

Strategies:

  •  Students must become acquainted with the teachers and staff of their departments and, more significantly, ensure that those faculty and staff members become acquainted with them.
  • Employer-Assisted Funding: Students who work will be interested to learn that their employers may be willing to contribute to the cost of their college education.
  • Tuition-Free and Work Universities: Tuition-free colleges admit students solely on merit and guarantee tuition payment coverage — and, in certain cases, other costs as well – regardless of financial ability.

There are a zillion additional ways to save money for college, such as:

  • In high school, take a lot of AP classes.
  • Before transferring to a four-year school, attend a community college for two years.
  • Consider living off-campus or, even better, living at home.
  • Work-study programs are available.
  • Preparing your own meals.

Some students have even proposed selling blood or volunteering as a guinea pig for medical research. Going that far may be overkill. The point is that obtaining money to pay for college often needs a little ingenuity — as well as time and effort.
